title: Interpretation of Shapley values returned by TreeShap for multiclass classification
body:
Dear @slundberg,
Thanks for creating such amazing tools to explain model's predictions. 

I am a bit confused with the interpretation of the Shapley values obtained by TreeShap for multiclass classification.

I have read in Molnar (2022) and Gianfagna (2021) books that the [TreeShap](https://shap-lrjball.readthedocs.io/en/latest/generated/shap.TreeExplainer.html) method returns the *exact* Shapley values of Shapley (1951).

The Shapley value estimates, given the current set of feature values, the **contribution** of a feature value to the difference between the actual prediction and the mean prediction.

I use the code below to compute the Shapley values through my trained XGBoost classifier:

    explainer = shap.TreeExplainer(xgb, X_test, model_output = "raw", feature_pertubation = "interventional")
    shapley_values = explainer.shap_values(X_test)

Now, if I look into the **first instance** for `class1` and I plot the absolut `nlargest=8` Shapley values I obtain:




[![][1]][1]

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/UnFhm.png

My interpretation is that Var1, with a Shapley value of 2, is the most discriminant variable for `instance1` to predict `class1` regardless of the feature `Value` < `Mean_class`. 

1. Is this the correct interpretation? 

2. What is the meaning of the negative Shapley value in `Var5`?

3. And, if it means that it has a negative contribution to predict `class1`, then, why is the SHAP feature importance the addition of the absolut mean in every instance (where it includes the negative Shapley values)?


I am struggling to find tutorials/examples to explain multilabel ensemble tree predictions via Shapley values. I would appreciate any link you may be aware of.

Best regards
